data.title: Advanced Clinical Management of Myasthenic Crisis in the Elderly Inpatient
data.subtitle: A Comprehensive Geriatric Report

data.sectionTitle: Introduction: The Evolving Landscape of MG in Geriatrics

data.title: The Epidemiological Shift of Myasthenia Gravis
data.content:
Key Paradigm Shift
Myasthenia Gravis has evolved from a disease of young women to predominantly affecting elderly patients (Late-Onset MG)

Historical vs. Contemporary View

  • Historical: Predominantly young women (20-40 years)
  • Contemporary: Bimodal distribution with larger peak at 60-80 years
  • LOMG: Now accounts for majority of cases in developed nations
  • Gender shift: Male predominance (~53%) in late-onset cases

Why This Matters in Geriatrics

  • Elderly rarely present with isolated neuromuscular dysfunction
  • Intersection of immunosenescence, polypharmacy, and frailty
  • Standard protocols must be rigorously adapted
  • "One-size-fits-all" approach is hazardous in this population

data.title: Early-Onset vs Late-Onset MG: Key Differences
data.leftColumn:
Early-Onset MG (<50 yrs)

  • Gender: Female predominance
  • Thymus: Hyperplasia common
  • Presentation: Generalized or ocular
  • Comorbidities: Autoimmune (thyroid, lupus)
  • Crisis triggers: Stress, menses, infection
  • Prognosis: 74.7% achieve MM status
data.rightColumn:
Late-Onset MG (>50 yrs)

  • Gender: Male predominance
  • Thymus: Atrophy or thymoma
  • Presentation: Oculobulbar prominent
  • Comorbidities: Cardiovascular, metabolic
  • Crisis triggers: Infection, drugs, surgery
  • Prognosis: 66.7% achieve MM status
Polypharmacy is a major modifiable risk factor in LOMG

data.trigger:
Autoantibody production against neuromuscular junction components
• 80-85% target nicotinic AChR
• Subset target MuSK (particularly dangerous in elderly)
data.mechanism:
Three mechanisms of AChR disruption:
1. Complement-mediated lysis: MAC formation destroys junctional folds
2. Cross-linking: Accelerates receptor endocytosis/degradation
3. Functional blockade: Direct blocking of ACh binding site
data.effects:
• Reduction in functional AChR density
• Decreased safety factor of NMJ transmission
• Superimposed on age-related NMJ fragmentation
• Progressive postsynaptic membrane damage
data.clinical:
• Fatigable muscle weakness
• Fluctuating symptoms (worse with activity)
• Bulbar dysfunction (dysphagia, dysarthria)
• Respiratory muscle weakness → Crisis
data.geriatricFactors:
Age-related NMJ changes:
• Natural fragmentation of postsynaptic membrane
• Reduced safety factor of transmission
• Thymic atrophy (but thymoma risk increases)
• MuSK-MG predilection for severe bulbar/respiratory weakness

data.title: The Insidious Onset of Crisis in the Elderly
data.content:
Definition: Myasthenic Crisis
Worsening of muscle weakness resulting in respiratory failure requiring intubation or non-invasive ventilation

Geriatric-Specific Presentation Challenges

  • Insidious rather than explosive: Gradual decline may be missed
  • Classic fluctuating weakness obscured by baseline sarcopenia
  • Mobility limitations from osteoarthritis mask weakness
  • Atypical presentations common

Bulbar Dominance: The Geriatric Signature

  • Predilection for bulbar muscles (speech, swallowing, chewing)
  • Upper airway collapse: Pharyngeal dilator weakness → obstructive apnea
  • Silent aspiration: Dysphagia → pneumonitis/pneumonia → immune response → worsens MG
Warning Signs: "Coughing while eating," "food sticking," nasal voice (rhinolalia), slurring (dysarthria), dropped head syndrome

data.title: The Differential Diagnosis Minefield
data.content:
MG: "The Great Imitator" in Geriatrics

MimicsDifferentiating FeaturesKey Tests
Stroke• MG: Symptoms fluctuate, no sensory deficits, no UMN signs
• Stroke: Fixed deficits, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign		CT/MRI Brain, AChR Ab
ALS/Motor Neuron Disease• MG: No UMN signs, no profound atrophy
• ALS: Fasciculations, UMN signs, progressive atrophy		EMG, NCS
Cholinergic Crisis• Muscarinic signs: miosis, bradycardia, hypersalivation, hyperactive bowel
• Both cause respiratory failure		Clinical exam, pyridostigmine level
Clinical Pearl: In elderly on beta-blockers (masking tachycardia) or with baseline bowel issues, distinguishing cholinergic crisis requires high clinical acumen

data.title: The "20/30/40" Rule: Respiratory Monitoring
data.content:
Critical Warning
Pulse oximetry is a LATE indicator of neuromuscular respiratory failure. A patient can maintain normal SpO2 until respiratory arrest due to precipitous hypercapnia!

Respiratory Function Parameters & Crisis Thresholds

ParameterNormalWarning ZoneCrisis Threshold
FVC>60 mL/kg<30 mL/kg<15-20 mL/kg (<1L)
NIF>-70 cmH2O-30 to -60 cmH2O0 to -30 cmH2O
MEP>100 cmH2O<50 cmH2O<40 cmH2O
Single Breath Count>50<25<15
Geriatric Tip: Single Breath Count is invaluable when spirometry fails due to poor dentition, cognitive impairment, or facial weakness. Count <15 ≈ FVC <1.0L

data.algoStart:
Patient with MG admitted to ward
Baseline FVC, NIF, SBC documented
data.algoDecision: Is patient in acute phase or newly symptomatic?
data.algoYes:
Acute Phase Protocol:
• FVC/NIF q2-4h
• Measure at pyridostigmine trough AND peak (1-2h post-dose)
• Continuous pulse oximetry
• Bedside swallow assessment
data.algoNo:
Stable Phase:
• FVC/NIF q8-12h
• Daily bedside assessment
• "Do Not Wake" if sleeping comfortably with normal RR
data.algoEnd:
Escalate to ICU if:
FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF >-30, SBC <15
or severe bulbar dysfunction
data.algoCitation: Adapted from MG crisis monitoring guidelines [7,13,14]

data.title: Bedside Swallowing Assessment
data.content:
Mandatory Bulbar Function Evaluation

High Risk for Silent Aspiration
Elderly MG patients with dysarthria, wet voice, or history of choking should be NPO pending formal FEES or videofluoroscopy

Assessment Protocol

  • Voice Quality Assessment:
    • Nasal twang (rhinolalia) = velopharyngeal weakness
    • Slurring (dysarthria) = tongue/lip weakness
    • Wet/gurgly voice = pooled secretions
  • Ice Pack Test: Primarily for ptosis diagnosis, NOT swallow
  • Bedside Water Swallow Test:
    • Minimum requirement if no clear bulbar signs
    • Observe for coughing, voice change, delayed swallow
  • Cough Strength Assessment: Peak Cough Flow <270 L/min = unable to clear secretions

Strict NPO Criteria

  • Any dysarthria or rhinolalia
  • Wet/gurgly voice quality
  • History of choking episodes
  • Dropped head syndrome (complicates airway management)

data.kpTitle: The Three Major Crisis Triggers in Elderly MG
data.kp1:
INFECTION (~50% of crises)
Most often pneumonia or UTI. Cytokine storm worsens NMJ blockade. Treat aggressively but BEWARE antibiotic choice!
data.kp2:
MEDICATION ERRORS
Polypharmacy is the #1 modifiable risk factor. New drug introduction is a common precipitant.
data.kp3:
SURGICAL/PHYSIOLOGICAL STRESS
Postoperative crisis common after thymectomy or unrelated surgery (e.g., hip fracture repair).
data.kp4:
High-Risk Surgical Factors:
• Blood loss >1000mL
• Prolonged anesthesia
• Pre-existing bulbar symptoms
data.kp5:
Infection Treatment Paradox:
Must treat infection aggressively, but many antibiotics worsen MG (fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, macrolides)
data.kp6:
Prevention is Key:
Medication reconciliation on every admission. Share "unsafe drug" list with all specialists.

data.content:

Neuro/PsychLithium, Phenytoin, Carbamazepine
Presynaptic blockade or membrane stabilization		Valproic Acid, Levetiracetam, Lamotrigine
MagnesiumIV Magnesium Sulfate

Avoid IV loading doses

Critical Alert: Oxybutynin
Commonly prescribed for incontinence in elderly. DIRECTLY CONTRAINDICATED in MG as it blocks the very receptors that MG treatment aims to stimulate!

data.sectionTitle: Acute Pharmacological Management: IVIG vs PLEX

data.title: Rapid Immunotherapy Selection in Geriatrics
data.leftColumn:
IVIG

Mechanism: Saturates Fc receptors, neutralizes autoantibodies, modulates complement

Efficacy

  • Onset: 4-5 days
  • Peak effect: 1-2 weeks

Geriatric Risks

  • Renal Toxicity: Osmotic nephrosis/AKI (sucrose formulations)
    Risk factors: Age >65, GFR <60, DM, dehydration
  • Thrombosis: Increased plasma viscosity → stroke, MI, DVT
  • Volume Overload: Risk of CHF exacerbation

Mitigation

  • Use sucrose-FREE formulations
  • Reduce infusion rate
  • Extend 2g/kg over 5 days (not 2-3)
data.rightColumn:
PLEX

Mechanism: Mechanically removes circulating autoantibodies, cytokines, immune complexes

Efficacy

  • Onset: 2-3 days
  • Faster than IVIG
  • Preferred in fulminant crisis

Geriatric Risks

  • Hemodynamic Instability: Hypotension in ~8% (autonomic dysfunction)
  • Vascular Access: Central line risks (pneumothorax, CLABSI, thrombosis) elevated in elderly
  • Citrate Toxicity: Hypocalcemia → paresthesias, arrhythmias

When to Choose

  • Severe renal failure (IVIG contraindicated)
  • Hemodynamically stable with rapid decline

data.title: IVIG vs PLEX: Clinical Decision Guide
data.content:
Clinical ScenarioPreferredRationale
Renal Failure (GFR <30)PLEXAvoids osmotic nephrosis risk of IVIG
Congestive Heart FailurePLEX (with albumin)IVIG volume load is high; PLEX allows precise fluid balance
Poor Venous AccessIVIGAvoids central line risks required for PLEX
Hypercoagulable StatePLEXIVIG increases viscosity; PLEX removes factors (monitor bleeding)
Fulminant/Rapid DeclinePLEXFaster onset of action (days vs. week)
Hemodynamic InstabilityIVIGPLEX can cause precipitous hypotension
In General Population
IVIG and PLEX are considered therapeutically equivalent. In geriatrics, the choice is dictated by the patient's comorbidity profile.

data.algoStart:
Patient with respiratory muscle weakness
FVC declining, NIF worsening
data.algoDecision:
Can patient protect airway?
• Intact cough (PCF >270 L/min)
• No severe bulbar dysfunction
• Alert and cooperative
data.algoYes:
Non-Invasive Ventilation (BiPAP)
• First-line intervention
• Prevents intubation in up to 70%
• IPAP supports tidal volume
• EPAP prevents atelectasis
• Reduces ICU/hospital LOS
data.algoNo:
Intubation Required
• Severe bulbar weakness (aspiration risk)
• PCF <270 L/min (can't clear secretions)
• Hypercapnic obtundation
• Positive pressure would force secretions into lungs
data.algoEnd: Primary Goal: Support respiration while immunotherapies take effect (days to 1-2 weeks)

data.title: Airway Clearance & NIV Contraindications
data.content:
Active Airway Clearance Techniques

  • Chest Physiotherapy: Standard percussion and vibration
  • Mechanical Insufflation-Exsufflation (MIE): CoughAssist devices for weak expiratory muscles
  • Suctioning: Frequent oral/nasopharyngeal for bulbar weakness patients

NIV Contraindications in MG

Bulbar Dysfunction: The Achilles' Heel of NIV
Severe bulbar weakness = cannot clear secretions. Positive pressure can FORCE secretions into lungs, causing aspiration!
ContraindicationRationaleAction
Severe bulbar dysfunctionCannot clear secretionsProceed to intubation
Hypercapnic coma/obtundationCannot protect airwayImmediate intubation
PCF <270 L/minIneffective coughIntubation for pulmonary toilet

data.title: Pyridostigmine & Corticosteroid Management
data.leftColumn:
Pyridostigmine (Mestinon)

Mechanism: Inhibits AChE breakdown, increases ACh at NMJ

Crisis Management

  • During intubation: Often WITHHELD
    • Reduces secretions (prolongs ventilation)
    • Avoids confusion with cholinergic crisis
  • Restart: Prior to extubation

Geriatric Dosing

  • Renal clearance ↓ with age
  • May need lower doses/longer intervals
  • Precise dosing critical:
    • Missing dose → weakness
    • Doubling up → cholinergic crisis
data.rightColumn:
Corticosteroids

The "Steroid Dip"
High-dose steroids (60mg/day) can cause PARADOXICAL WORSENING in ~15% of patients after 5-10 days, potentially precipitating crisis!

Safe Initiation Strategy

  • Option 1: "Start low, go slow"
    • Begin 10-20mg, titrate up
  • Option 2: High-dose ONLY after stabilization with IVIG/PLEX

Bone Health (Essential)

  • Calcium + Vitamin D
  • Bisphosphonates
    • Note: Rare reports of alendronate worsening MG
    • Monitor, but benefit usually outweighs risk

data.title: Dysphagia, Nutrition & Delirium Management
data.content:
Nutritional Support

  • Enteral Feeding (NG tube): Preferred in acute crisis
    • Less invasive than PEG
    • Suitable for transient crisis
    • Route for medications
  • PEG Tubes: Reserved for refractory bulbar weakness post-crisis
    • Does NOT prevent aspiration of saliva

Delirium Management Challenges

Standard Treatments Can Worsen MG!
  • Benzodiazepines: ABSOLUTELY CONTRAINDICATED (respiratory depression)
  • Antipsychotics: Haloperidol, olanzapine, quetiapine have anticholinergic properties
    Use ONLY if essential for safety, at lowest possible dose

Anxiety Management

  • Anxiety often = "air hunger" → treat respiratory failure!
  • If anxiolysis essential: ONLY in monitored setting with ventilation available

data.title: Falls Prevention & Mobility
data.content:
Understanding Fatigable Weakness

Myasthenic weakness is fatigable - worse in the evening or after exertion. This has direct implications for fall risk and therapy timing.

Fall Risk Patterns

  • Highest risk: Evening hours
  • Highest risk: Before next pyridostigmine dose (drug trough)
  • Lowest risk: Peak drug effect times

Therapy Timing Optimization

ActivityOptimal TimingRationale
Physiotherapy45-60 min post-pyridostigminePeak drug effect = maximum strength
MobilizationMorning, post-medicationLeast fatigue, best drug effect
Swallowing therapyPeak drug timesOptimal bulbar function
ADL practiceAvoid late afternoon/eveningMinimize fatigable weakness

data.title: Discharge Planning Essentials
data.content:
Discharge Planning Must Begin on Admission
The complexity of LOMG management requires proactive coordination with PCP, specialists, and caregivers

Medication Reconciliation & Education

  • "Safe" and "Unsafe" Medication List:
    • Patient copy
    • PCP notification
    • All specialists (urologist, cardiologist) must receive list
    • Prevent future prescription of oxybutynin, beta-blockers, fluoroquinolones

Vaccination Requirements

VaccineRecommendationNotes
InfluenzaAnnual - RequiredRespiratory infection = #1 crisis trigger
PneumococcalRequiredPer age-appropriate guidelines
Shingles (Zostavax - live)CONTRAINDICATEDIf on prednisone >20mg, azathioprine, mycophenolate
Shingles (Shingrix - recombinant)PreferredSafe alternative for shingles prevention

data.title: Home Monitoring & Patient Education
data.content:
Self-Monitoring Techniques

Single Breath Count Self-Test
Patient counts out loud on a single breath. A decrease from baseline count is an early warning of respiratory decline. Count <15 = seek immediate medical attention!

Warning Signs Requiring Immediate Attention

  • Swallowing:
    • Difficulty finishing a meal
    • Coughing with liquids
    • Food "sticking" sensation
  • Breathing:
    • Single breath count decreasing
    • Morning headaches (CO2 retention)
    • Orthopnea (worse lying flat)
  • General:
    • Increasing fatigue pattern
    • New infection symptoms (fever, cough, dysuria)
    • After starting ANY new medication

Prognosis Discussion

  • Acute mortality of crisis is low (~4-6%)
  • Recovery of full strength may take MONTHS
  • Focus on optimizing functional status
  • Strict medication adherence + infection control = recurrence prevention

data.message1:
EARLY RECOGNITION
Use objective respiratory metrics (FVC, NIF, SBC) over subjective symptoms. Pulse oximetry is a LATE indicator!
data.message2:
TARGETED INTERVENTION
Select IVIG vs PLEX based on comorbidity profile, not protocol. Renal, cardiac, and vascular status dictate choice.
data.message3:
RIGOROUS PREVENTION
Iatrogenic crisis from polypharmacy is the most preventable cause. Know the "dangerous drug" list - especially fluoroquinolones and oxybutynin.
data.message4:
MULTIDISCIPLINARY APPROACH
Success requires coordination: neurology, pulmonology, geriatrics, pharmacy, PT/OT, speech therapy, and nursing.
data.bottomLine: The management of myasthenic crisis in the elderly demands departure from standard protocols - navigating a narrow therapeutic window between aggressive immunosuppression and the fragility of aging organ systems.

data.teachingPoints:
1

The "20/30/40" Rule

FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF >-30 cmH2O, or SBC <15 = impending respiratory failure. Don't wait for desaturation!

2

Bulbar Dysfunction = NIV Contraindication

Severe bulbar weakness prevents secretion clearance. BiPAP can force secretions into lungs. These patients need intubation.

3

The Steroid Dip

~15% of patients paradoxically worsen 5-10 days after high-dose steroid initiation. Start low-go slow, or start high only after IVIG/PLEX stabilization.

4

Fluoroquinolones: FDA Black Box Warning

Reports of DEATH from respiratory failure in MG patients. Consider absolutely contraindicated unless no other option exists.

5

Time Your Therapies

Schedule PT, mobilization, and swallowing therapy 45-60 minutes post-pyridostigmine to maximize function and minimize fall risk.
